text:
So hi, everyone. Yeah. Thanks for having
me here at Stanford. As [INAUDIBLE] mentioned,
I'm Blase from the University

of Chicago. And I'll be talking
about a series of projects I've done with my
students in the SUPERgroup.

So we're a big collective
of researchers focusing on security, privacy,
human-computer interaction,

ethical AI systems. Now, large language
models like everyone else. Whatever my students
find interesting,

I find interesting, too. And there are a lot
of different things I could have talked about today
and lots of different topic

areas, but I decided to focus
today's talk exclusively on privacy.

And to set the stage
for this, I'll actually go through an
exercise I use when I teach undergraduate classes
on privacy to introduce like,

what do we mean by privacy? And specifically, what I'm
going to talk about is a book.

It's a photography book, which
you might wonder, what does this have to do with privacy?

And we'll get there. It also has to do, of course,
with one of my hobbies, of which I have
too many, according

to everyone from my PhD
advisor to my sister. And so photography is one
of my favorite things.

When I was thinking
about moving to Chicago, accepting this job at
University of Chicago, I went to one of Chicago's
many great museums,

which is focused on
photography, saw this book. And it's called The
Transparent City

by this photographer,
Michael Wolf. And this book, it's
architectural photography.

A big coffee table book. I started flipping through it. And it's really beautiful. It shows the growth of
the Downtown Chicago area.

The Loop, River North,
these amazing buildings, beautiful symmetry, lots
of really straight lines,
some wavy lines. You go through the book. Lots of lights.

If you're a fan of
20-year-old dad rock, you'd probably recognize
the buildings on the right

as a famous album cover. And so I was looking
through this book and flipping through admiring
these beautiful photos.

And I came across a photo
that really turns out caught the photographer's
eye, and this particular photo

also caught my eye. I'm from New Jersey. And so I immediately
recognized this as our official state gesture,
a person giving you the finger.

And so what's the
deal with this? Well, so this
person was actually

caught in one of the photos
once the photographer zoomed in. To quote the photographer,
"One evening, I

was looking at a
photograph I had shot, and I saw a man giving
me the middle finger. It set off a chain
reaction in me,

and I began to look
through every file at 200% magnification to
see what else was going on in those windows.

I saw hands on computer mice and
family photographs on the desks of CEOs; I saw people
watching flat screen TVs."

And so this book is actually
half architectural photos and half zoomed in photos or
photos alternatively taken

with telephoto lenses of
people inside their homes or their offices.

And I think it's a
really interesting way to get my classes talking
about privacy, saying, is this a privacy violation?

Are these photographs
of privacy violation? And what I find typically
is some students

will say, yes, some
students will say, no. And most of the time, students
will say, well, it depends.

And they start asking questions. They start saying,
first of all, well, did people know they were being
photographed beforehand or even

afterwards? Did they consent to this? And was this a
affirmative consent?

Are they being paid for this? How are these photos being used? Is it being used commercially? And they look through
these different photos,

and sometimes
they'll say, well, it depends on what they're doing. Maybe a person having dinner
is not a privacy violation,

but a person with some
regrettable tattoos or a person watching TV with bad
posture, maybe those

are privacy violations. And they start asking
even more questions. They'll look at this, and some
of these people are in offices.

And they'll say, well, maybe
it's not a privacy violation if they're in their office,
but it's a privacy violation

if they're in their home. And they start
differentiating there. They'll also ask
questions like, well, what floor were these people on?

And maybe if they're
in the first or second, maybe even third floor,
it's not a privacy violation because anyone walking
down the street can see it.

But if they're on
the upper floor, well, maybe it is a
privacy violation, because people walking down
the street couldn't see it.

And then they'll get into
discussions of like, well, the upper floors are usually
a lot more expensive. So is privacy a right
only for the rich?

They'll ask even more questions. They'll look at some of
these pictures and say, this person is not identifiable.

Well, does being identifiable,
is that necessary to consider it a
privacy violation?

They'll look at other people
and say, well, it's pixelated. Maybe the pixelation makes it
not a privacy violation or maybe

it doesn't matter. Maybe what act a person
is engaging in matters.

Is a facial recognition
system being used? Can we identify these
people post-hoc? Are they in some databases?

And all these externalities
are factoring into whether they say it's a
privacy violation or not. And then I'd like to save some
of the images towards the end.

The photographer
shot through blinds. Well, the blinds aren't
stopping the photographer from shooting these people.

But is this a
signaling mechanism? Does the fact that these people
maybe had their blinds down

signal that they didn't
want their photo taken? Well, how do we think
about signaling mechanisms?

And so overall, this gets the
students talking and privacy ends up being
really complicated.

And this is something--
what is privacy is a question that's
been asked by lots of people over the years.

Technologists, legal
scholars, philosophers, communication experts. And a lot of this
in the US, at least,

traces back to the first
articulations of a right to privacy in 1890,

Samuel Warren and
Louis Brandeis, the latter of whom
ended up becoming, later in his career, a
Supreme Court justice,

where they basically
were looking at well, do we have a right to privacy? And they were actually
inspired by the rise

of instantaneous
photography, which is why I think it's a really
nice parallel that this Michael Wolf's photography book
got me thinking about this.

So they noticed that in
high society gatherings,

people were suddenly
being photographed. It was the gossip
magazines of the 1890s.

And so they centered
on like, OK. Well , seems like we should
have the right to be let alone.

They go through a
long legal analysis of other possible rights. And they said, the
right to privacy seems like something different.

The right to say, I don't
want to participate in this. Leave me alone. And over the 20th century, a lot
of great scholars refine this

right. Alan Westin talked about maybe
we have this notion of privacy as control. You should be able to control
information disclosures.

But then social psychologists
started thinking, well, sometimes you want to
give away information.

Do you basically give
up your privacy rights, if you give away information
of your own volition?

So Irwin Altman,
Sandra Petronio, others started refining
what could this mean? And this refinement has
continued into the 21st century.

You have Dan Solove, who is
a legal scholar who basically wrote these beautiful articles.

One of my favorites
is called the-- I forget exactly
what it's called,

you have nothing to fear. That actually has
nothing to say. And privacy is actually
a lot of different things all rolled up together.

Helen Nissenbaum came up
with this theory called contextual integrity,
which basically says, well, there is appropriate
flows of information--

inappropriate flows
of information. And we can start
thinking about what is and what's not appropriate.

And that's all guided by
social norms and expectations. And it's a really rich way
of thinking about privacy.

But this is all getting
maybe a little philosophical. And I'm a technologist. I like building things.

And so I often look at
concretely, well, what are privacy principles? How do we think
about what guides us

when we build systems,
especially interactive systems. Those that engage with humans.

So back in the
mid-20th century, lots of governments and
non-governmental organizations

were grappling
with like, what are privacy principles we
should have as we're moving into a data-based economy.

And this was happening,
even back in the 1960s. And a lot of different
organizations came up with similar
articulations.

But one of my favorites is from
the US Federal Trade Commission and their Fair Information
Practice Principles or FIPPs.

And they said things like, well,
you should have these rights. You should conceptually
receive notice

if data is being collected. Have some choice about this. Be able to access the
data collected about you.

We should be able to ensure
the integrity of the data, both the security of the
data so that it's not stolen and that it's accurate
and not altered.

And there should also be
enforcement of all of this. So these were conceptual
principles, not particular laws.

But regardless of that, we
were governed for many years by what a lot of people consider
a notice and choice framework.

So even though there are
five principles listed, notice and choice are
the ones you've probably encountered the most
over your own lifetimes.

And so notice in
choice, that's you're told something is
potentially going to happen

and you arguably have some
choice and arguably maybe don't have any choice. And the way this
manifests is often things

like go to a website, and you
see a cookie consent banner and you kind of play this
ridiculous game where

you try and find the No button. The No button sometimes involves
lots of different clicks.

So that's the consent part
of it, as well as notice. But notice itself, in
my opinion, is a failed.

And just for a
exhibit about this, let's look at
Stanford's web page,

which I went to trying to figure
out how to get here yesterday. So go to stanford.edu,
scroll down to the bottom,

and click on Privacy. And there's an online
privacy policy. So I started reading,
and I kept reading,

and I kept reading,
and going, and going. All right. We're finally in section 2. And it kept going, going, going,
going, going, going, going.

And I finally got to the end. And no. I did not actually read this. I had to finish
making these slides.

Well, this doesn't
seem very useful. I'm receiving notice, but
I go to a lot of websites.

This is not a very effective
way of thinking about privacy. And it's also so abstract.

I'm not a lawyer. I have no legal training. I'm usually on the
wrong side of the law.

And so I'm certainly not the
person to be thinking about, what does this all mean for
me on this abstract world?

And so that said,
there are privacy laws, and it differs based
on where you're living.

What rights you have or
what rights you don't have. So, for instance, in
the European Union,

there's the General Data
Privacy regulation or GDPR. And so GDPR was passed in
2016, came into effect in 2018,

and you've probably
heard about it. When GDPR came into effect, you
probably got a lot of emails.

And not much else
happened, seemingly. So what rights did it give us?

Well, it basically said that
people in the European Union have certain rights
related to privacy.

The right to request
data be erased, the right to object to certain
types of data processing

that if there's a data breach,
the company is required to let you know very quickly. And right of access to
information collected about you,

and we'll come back to this. That privacy should be built
into these systems by design and not bolted on at
the end, as my PhD

advisor likes to point out. That just doesn't work. You can't retroactively
retrofit privacy into a system.

And so in the US, we don't have
nationally anything like GDPR,

yet or maybe ever. Well, it remains to be seen. But historically, the US has had
what are known as sectoral laws.

And so essentially,
different aspects of privacy have their own laws.

So children have their
own privacy law governing how children's data is used.

Those of you who
signed up for services when you were under 13 years
old have violated this law.

But it serves a really
important purpose in trying to protect
children's privacy. So children are an entity
whose privacy is important.

And we care about financial
data, credit reporting. There's the FCRA.

We care about educational data,
FERPA, which you, I'm sure, encounter in your
classes here at Stanford.

We care about health data. These seem all really
important aspects of privacy

where the data privacy of
these different dimensions of our lives really matters.

Does anyone want to
guess, I have one more law I'm about to put up. In addition to children,
financial data,

educational data, health data. Anyone want to guess
what else is protected?
Video rental records. And you might ask why? Why? Why video rental records?

And it comes back
to in the 1980s, there was a nominee
for the Supreme Court. This nomination did not
actually, in the end,

go through. But various newspapers
started saying, let's try and dig up some
dirt on this nominee.

So they went to this
nominee's local video store and said, well, what
did this person rent? And so this is very reactive.

But a lot of these privacy
laws are really reactive. And the US, it hasn't been you
have this deep, long standing

right to privacy. We don't actually, in fact,
have that at all explicitly in the Constitution.

What we have had traditionally
are these sectoral laws. But the European Union,
in terms of privacy law,

has been putting
the US to shame. And so different states in
the US have tried to catch up. And most notably, since
I'm here in California,

California has been
arguably the main leader in this in terms of US states
with the California Consumer

Privacy Act or CCPA,
just passed in 2018, went into effect
two years later, and CPRA, which amended CCPA.

And actually, Illinois
has yet to catch up, but a number of other
states have since then. And I'm not going
to go into this,

but there have been some pushes
for national US privacy law, like GDPR.

We're not there yet. Although, as of a few weeks
ago, some of these ideas have been revived. I thought this was
completely off the table,

but it's back, maybe. But CCPA, CPRA give
Californians a lot

of the same rights as GDPR. Some extra rights. Let's not worry
about those for right

now, because what I
really want to worry about is this data-driven
world we live in.

So a bunch of you are probably
excited about machine learning, large language models, that's
the in thing in computing

right now. And a lot of this is
just driven by data. A lot of data has to
be collected about you

to drive these models. Large language models don't
work without lots of data.

And again, data
comes from people. And so when I came to
University of Chicago,

we had started expanding
rapidly in the computer science department, but also building
up a data science effort.

And this is something where
we had these questions like, well, what is data science,
what does this all mean?

And had some colleagues
mentioned to me, "data is the new oil
quoting," this mathematician

and entrepreneur. And I realized after talking
to them for a little bit.
They meant this as a good thing. They said, data is the new oil. There's so much potential.

This is going to drive
so much innovation. And the whole time we had
been talking up to that point, I had been thinking
that they're saying data

is the new oil, as
if it's a bad thing. Sometimes you're
digging in the ground and this liquid just
starts spurting up,

and you go to touch it and
your hands get really dirty. The more you touch it, the
dirtier your hands get.

And it's really
hard to wash it off. Data, just like oil, causes
is a couple of people

often to make a lot of money
and a lot of other people to be marginalized economically. Cause lots of
geopolitical conflict.

And so I was like, yeah. Data is the new oil. And then I realized we were
just talking about completely different things.

So how does data-driven world? And I like large language
models in some cases. I use them in some
of my own research.

I'm frenemies with
machine learning. Sometimes they
build classifiers, and sometimes I'm
an angry person

yelling at the clouds
about the classifiers. But how does this all
intersect with privacy?

And we often hear, if we read
the news, privacy is dead.

I could have filled the
screen with lots of privacy is dead newspaper articles. I just gave you two.

So what does it mean
that privacy is dead, in this data-driven world. So what is privacy?

Privacy is dead. How? And so this is-- I, one time, went
to a talk with--

giving a talk like this
at another university. This is intentional. Yeah. Yeah.

I want you to all listen to me. Stop looking at the screen. Don't be just focused
on screens at all times.

Our life does not need to
be mediated by screens. So I was at this university
like this talking.

At that time, I actually
had something on the screen. And it was my title slide. And so I was about to
start giving a talk.

And I got a question
from the audience. And when you get a question
from the audience on your title slide, you're in trouble.

And so this person goes, and
it was a talk about privacy. And the question
was, privacy is dead.

And I was like, well,
that's not a question. That's a statement. And this person said, well,
there's social media now.

There's no such
thing as privacy. This new generation, we've
moved beyond privacy. What are you going
to give a talk about?

This thing is dead. And so then I asked the
question asker, well,

can you please tell me the
password to your laptop, hand me over your laptop.

I'll log into all of
your financial sites, start telling me about
your intimate relationships with your family.

And also, please
disrobe right now. And this gentleman refused. And I said, well, OK.

Clearly privacy is
not dead, if you don't want to do these things. So what does privacy mean?

And I learned later that was
actually the dean of engineering at that university. And so I probably should
not have sassed this person.

But it's got me thinking,
how does privacy interact

with data-driven world? And can we actually use
data to better understand

privacy and actually use data
in some ways as a good thing? And so I'm going to talk for
the next about 25 minutes or so

about different efforts we've
done, providing transparency about online tracking.

And I'll start, since
this is an HCI seminar, with a particular
user study, which

I think gives some
insight into this world. And this is a world where we go
online, and a lot of the things

we do online are tracked by all
these different companies using things like cookies
or fingerprints

or potentially I could
added sandboxes onto there, since this is the next
frontier in mechanisms

for tracking what we do. But things are
concluded about us, and this drives a lot
of online targeted ads

and personalization
and things like that. All right. So first, you all talk
about this user study

we published at
the CHI conference a couple of years ago about
taking data out of context to hyper-personalized ads.

And so I've been talking to some
of my colleagues and students about, well, what does it mean
to use data to personalize ads?

And is it going to reach
a point where people are like, this is just too creepy. I'm not going to participate
in this ecosystem anymore.

Are we going to have a citizen
revolt against, just stop. This is too much. And so we said,
well, let's maybe

test a variant of this
in a deception study. Deception study, meaning people
participating in the study

didn't actually know
what the study was about. But you have to
put a lot of care

into how you do this ethically. They're debriefing. Requirements both legally
as well as ethically.

And I'm happy to talk
to any of you who are interested in
these kinds of studies. But the design of the
study was between subjects.

So different people
were assigned to different conditions. And so half of the people were
shown what we call a generic ad.

Treat yourself this
week, use SUPEReats to reserve a restaurant
near you for a deal.

And so my students
really liked that. I was paying them as
a research assistant to have flying French fries.

And we said, half the people-- actually, in fact, we're
going to get this generic ad as this banner ad inside
our survey platform,

which led to some interesting
feedback from people like, you poor university
people, you have to use the ad-supported
free version of Qualtrics.

Does not exist. So the other half, we
were concerned that people weren't going to believe this.

So we actually sent
them robo text from one of those short numbers. While they were participating
in the study early on,

automatically they
got these texts right. So half the people, whether they
saw a banner ad or a robot text,

got this generic ad. The other half of
people got what we called a hyper-targeted ad. Taylor, treat Ryan to a date
night this week in Memphis.

We know you love
Thai restaurants. Use SUPEReats to reserve a
table at one of the 7 near you for a deal.

And so how do we
hyper-target this? It was actually a
multi-part study. So a few weeks prior,
we had people sign up

to do an initial study. Again, not knowing
what it was about. And amidst a bunch of
distractor questions,

we found out their name,
their relationship status. If they were in a relationship,
their partner's first name.

We did some IP geolocation to
figure out where they were. We asked them questions
about a whole bunch of things they liked, including
cuisines they liked.

And so everyone, a couple of
weeks later, when they came back for a follow-up study, and
it turns out almost everyone

had forgotten. They gave us this information. They were really
creeped out, the people who got these targeted ads.

So we got back to our
short code texting number.

Well, we were accused of being-- some people thought we
were Grubhub gone wild.

And so we got lots of
messages of like, how dare you use this information to
target an ad towards me,

thinking that we were actually
the restaurant platform. And so people were
really creeped out,

which was one of our
response variables. But we also had--
subsequently in the study,

they had gotten this
robo text or banner ad, and we asked them a bunch
of personal questions with the opportunity to opt out.

And we thought that people
who were creeped out right when they were
starting to fill out this big battery
of questions would

be less likely to disclose
personal information. The types of
personal information we used to target them, in fact.

And we did not
find a difference. And so we were
like, this is weird. We reran the study,
pretending we

weren't University of Chicago. Working with your
institutional review board to pretend not only that the
study is about a different thing

than it is, but that you're a
different entity than you are. Involved a lot of
discussion and negotiation.

But we were able
to do it in a way that we all felt
comfortable with ethically. And we had a huge
debriefing process for this,

including for people who
dropped out of the study. But so in other words, what
we saw from this was like, people were creeped
out, but they weren't

changing their behavior. And so what does this
tell us about privacy?

So from that, we said,
well, maybe if people better understood what was going on,
they would act differently.

And so we've been, over
the last few years, building a series of
tools to try and provide

been punning a Dr. Seuss story
that my student, Ben and others

led. What we did is we looked at
the space of existing privacy transparency tools
and found out,

they didn't really
tell us all that much that I found interesting. Yeah. But that's a [INAUDIBLE]--

Sure. [INAUDIBLE] previous slide. Yeah, yeah. So here, if S is the trust
was whether to believe this,

take a process. If the user has been
interacting with this website, let's say for a few
times, it's probably OK

that the website
can tell their name and their favorite
cuisine versus

if you just expose me to
this for the first time, it's shocking. Have you come to the
fore of this, I guess,

established process of
familiarity or trust with the platform? Yeah, yeah, yeah.

So we try to unpack
these results. Students and I talked
for a long time.

We talked to
colleagues and privacy across a bunch of different
universities trying to understand these
possible factors of trust in a platform, trust
in research studies,

like maybe people
are disclosing. This was part of
the explanation. People trust-- if they're
giving data for research,

they might be more willing
to do this than to a company. And yeah. So there is a lot going on
in trying to unpack this.

But I think for me,
the high-level takeaway is data is taken out of context.

You often don't know
where the data came from. And so it's hard to reason
about trust in a platform where,

a lot of the people who-- in our study who
receive these messages, how did you get my name?

How do you know that I'm
dating Ryan, that thing. And even when we told them
during the debrief, well,

you told us this
a couple of weeks ago, they didn't
believe us, which was-- it's interesting because your
data just goes everywhere,

and it's hard to
make sense of it. And so that's in these
subsequent efforts. We're trying to help
people make sense of it.

And the existing
tools we have, they'll say like, this blue CHI
is tracking you right now

or we've blocked 11
trackers of the 25 people who are trying to
track you or whatever.

And what do I do with
this information? It seems vague and abstract.

And so those are
third-party privacy tools. Even companies own efforts
at transparency are also

really vague and abstract. Google says-- when I ask Google
what interests it thinks I have,

like cooking and recipes. Like, yes. Everyone likes
cooking and recipes.

Who doesn't like dinner? And so this doesn't square
with if you go sign up

as an advertiser to
target ads on Google, it's not cooking in recipes.

You have much, much more
specific topics that you're able to target ads on.

And in fact, it's even more-- if you're using various
social platforms, there's tens of thousands
of different categories

on which you can target ads. So we built this
browser extension that we call tracking
transparency.

And what it does is it locally
on your own web browser, in our extension, records
you being tracked.

And metadata about the page,
the contents of the page. We built our own shadow
model running locally

on your machine to say,
what is this page About? What ad topics might this imply?

And it helps you visualize
what's been tracked about you.

So we worked with some
information visualization colleagues. They were really into these
sunburst visualizations.

They were really not
into the word clouds, but our participants were. So we just went with
the data, and we showed,

these are all the different
things Google might think you're interested in. And we actually inadvertently
ended up also being vague.

We did it based on what were
the most common categories, and I'll revisit this right
at the end of the talk.

But it had some impact
on people's perceptions, but less than I
thought it would.

Showing people data about
how they had been tracked and what could be learned
about them didn't really

create this firestorm of,
we need to protect privacy. We need to stop this
online tracking.

And so then my students and I
got really interested in, well, what can we do that's
better than this?

Can we actually leverage
privacy laws to do better?

And it turns out, going back
to not notice and choice, but access, this third principle
from the Fair Information

Practice Principles,
that actually helped us because GDPR gives a right
of access to data subjects,

so does CCPA, CPRA. Right of access means you
can go to a company meeting

certain requirements. So generally, larger
companies that collect personal data, which is
a lot of the larger companies.

And you have a right to get
a copy of your personal data. And this actually led us
to do, a couple of years

ago, an analysis of how ads are
being targeted on the Twitter ecosystem.

And so I had gone into this
project thinking that the way ads were targeted
on Twitter was based

on things like my gender
identity, my location, in broad strokes, my interests.

And this does happen. But it turns out there's a lot
more going on with ad targeting.

The reality is,
you're being targeted like you went to
the grocery store and have regularly bought
organic ketchup on your loyalty

card and lots of
other information about things you're doing
that are much more specific.

And the way we were
able to understand this was enabled by these data
subject access rights.

So we had a few hundred Twitter
users volunteer for a study and volunteer to
download their own data,

and share with us actually
just one of the files that they got back from Twitter
under these data access rights.

There is this file
my students had found called ad impressions,
which was a JSON object.

Very long of what
turned out to be all the ads that had been shown
to you on Twitter in the last 90

days. And one of the things that
was really interesting to us as we were going
through this file was this matched
targeting criteria key.

And we were like, does
this mean the criteria that were matched
to you specifically? Because this is
actually a lot more

than if you click, why did
I get this ad on Twitter as my students were spending
months tracking their own data,

downloading their data every few
weeks and tracking all the ads they were seeing on
Twitter clicking, why did they get this ad. And so we found a European to
invoke their privacy rights.

And they corresponded with
Twitter's Data Protection Office and confirmed that indeed--

took us a number of months
to get the answer that, yes, match targeting criteria does
mean what we thought it meant.

So we said, this
is so interesting. Let's do a study about this. So again, we had
hundreds of people request their Twitter data,
upload their ad-related data

to us, and take a
customized survey. All right. So the 231 participants
in our study,

they had been on Twitter
an average of over 6 years, had been shown over 1,000 ads
on average in the last 90 days.

And we found actually over
45,000 unique targeting types.

So location equals Chicago,
will be one targeting type. Location equals Palo Alto
is a second targeting type.

Interests equals trees is like
a third, that sort of a thing. And so we saw not just interest
and demographics, but things

like-- behavioral inferences
or maybe even just stereotypes
of your behavior

maybe a less charitable
interpretation. As well as things
tailored audiences.

And this is something I
hadn't been familiar with. Advertisers could
upload lists containing

hashes of personal identifiers. So hash of your Twitter
username, hash of your phone number, which also happens to
be the phone number you use

for your grocery store card. And they could say who they
wanted, included or excluded from their ad campaign.

And so Twitter's
terms of service prohibit targeting on race,
religion, sex, life, health,

# like unemployment,
gay, #AfricanAmerican being used to target ads.

Conversation topics like
the Liberal Democrats political party in the UK. And then tailored lists.

These are, again hashes
of personal identifiers. And these are names that
the advertising company gave

to the lists when
they uploaded it for their own convenience,
presumably not realizing this would be
shared with data subjects.

And we de-identified these. Account status-- balance due,
Christian audience to exclude,

LGBT suppression list. And my students saw this,
and we're like, well, OK.

This is not OK that
our web experience is being targeted in these ways.

And this is a lot more
concrete to my students. I mean, specifically,
my students said, well,

what is part of this? How can we provide
better ad explanation? So we reverse engineered
how Twitter used this data

to generate ad explanations. Again, my students saw,
what was in their data and what they actually saw
on the Twitter platform?

We did a similar
thing of how Facebook would generate ad explanations. And then we made our own. We made these speculative
ad explanations

with a lot more detail, either
text or being slightly better designers, some more visuals.

And we ran, as part of this
data-driven customized study

of Twitter users, within
subjects evaluation, comparing-- again with people not
realizing which was which.

Randomized order, all the proper
things to do in study design. How people reacted to these
different Twitter-like ad

explanations, Facebook-like ad
explanations and the kinds we came up with, as well as a
control of-- basically saying,

you got this ad because the
advertiser bought an ad. And what we found is our
participants much preferred

the things we had come up
with more detail about how they were being targeted. And so we said, OK.

Well, clearly we can do
better as a community on this, if we wanted to. And we have a
whole other project

that's ongoing on how do you
build better ad explanations, and how do we actually compare
what all different entities are

doing right now. But we also got
much more interested in this right of data access.

So my students-- especially
my student, Sophie, saw how people
were being targeted and we were like, if only people
actually looked at their data

and knew what was going
on, they would be shocked. And so we said, well,
look, maybe let's

ramp up some projects
saying, can we actually make the right of data access
something much more meaningful

for privacy? And so Sophie and a number
of our other students led this study on
basically saying, what

could data access rights be? And particularly, it
was a co-design study. So we had participants
download their data.

And so if you've never
downloaded your data, and probably most
of you never have, what you get is actually
often like a big JSON

file or a series of JSON
files or a bunch of CSV comma separated value files.

If you download your
data from Google, you get a gigantic zip file. If you're like, oh. I wonder what happens if I try
and download a 40-gigabyte file,

download your Google data. If you've ever said, well,
how big can a JSON file get?

Download your data from
many other companies. And what we did is we had
people download their data

and participate in remote
co-design focus groups. So we had 42 participants
across 12 focus groups,

each downloading their data
from an assigned company. And they basically-- we had them
come through our focus group,

explore their own data
on their own machine, not sharing it with
each other, or us, talk about what they were
seeing, and engage

in a number of co-design
activities, where they said, well, if you wanted to have
an interface for your data,

show you the information
that's contained in this data, what could it be? So again, these
are just end users

engaging in speculative design. And we abstract
it out from this. What could the
design be of helping

people explore their data? I mean, one of the things
we noticed is actually, a lot of our participants,
when they first

got-- we found this
out and piloting, address this by the main study. They didn't even know
how to open these files.

They got a JSON file and
couldn't figure out-- they had to pick a
text editor to open it. And some of them, they tried to
open it in their text editor,

and it crashed. They would get zip files,
didn't understand how to unpack those files.

So even just accessing
the data was a barrier. But once they were able
to get to the data, they often felt overwhelmed.

They felt some summarization
tools were needed. So while these data
downloads they were getting

were compliant with
their data access rights, they weren't very
useful to participants. That's said, they didn't
want just the summaries.

They wanted to be
able to explore, to search for specific
memories, both because they wondered, does this
company have this data on me,

or also to revisit
particular memories. Nostalgia, as part of
personal informatics,

is a really powerful tool. But then also this idea of
being able to audit companies. But beyond just searching
and exploring their own data,

they were interested
in comparing their data in privacy-preserving
ways with other people, and just understanding, well,
what does this all mean?

How is it used? Why does the company have this? And these, by and
large, were things

that are not supported by
current data access rights. And so we've been continuing
our follow-up work

and work that my students,
Arthur and Elleen, will be presenting at this
year's USENIX Security Symposium in August, and are
actually presenting

at USENIX PEPR in Santa Clara,
just a little South of here next week, in fact.

A week and a half from now. We did a follow-up study that
was much more quantitative.

What we did is knowing that
so many of our participants in our previous study had
trouble exploring their data,

we built-- and by we, I mean my students-- Arthur and Elleen
and their colleagues

built this React app that helped
people explore their data, search through their
data, understand

how to parse these files. But then a big part
of our study was we had people annotate
subsections of their data

to understand, well, what
did they find interesting, and what did they find creepy? What did they find
confusing or did they not

understand to help
us understand, how can we build a better tool.

And we also asked participants
like, what are questions-- before they looked at their
data, what are questions they

would want to have answered? They want to things
like what data is stored, how the data
is being stored and used,

what are some of their
high-level takeaways and implications from the data. And a lot of these
things were not

answered by just roughly
exploring their data. Even though we provided these
search and exploration features,

there's still a long way to go
to make this a much more useful. Participants were also often
confused by undefined terms.

There aren't like
data dictionaries provided by and large
for these data downloads.

Things like these are often
machine readable data downloads. And they're actually
rights I didn't talk about

for data portability. The idea that I could download
my Twitter data or X data and now move to a different
computing platform.

These are parts of
privacy laws and data, protection laws as well, often. And that needs to be in
machine-readable format.

But these data downloads,
often, but not always, are in machine-readable format. So our participants were
seeing these crazy numbers

and they're like, what
is this wild number? It's a Unix timestamp. But why would this if you
haven't studied computer

science or data science? And so we're currently
in the process of building what we call
the data access illuminator

tool and ecosystem. And our idea is, we want to help
consumers understand the scope and implications of the personal
data collected about them

through their own data. Having these richer
tools for people to perform personal data
science on their own data

without needing to
know data science. Visualizing it in
interesting ways, giving them the opportunity
to compare themselves

with others using different
private computation and other fancy
crypto techniques.

And so this is, in
general, this ecosystem that we're hoping to
really push forward to reframe the narrative of how
people interact with their data.

Because right now, when
you go ask a company through their privacy dashboard,
what data do you have about me,

they get to control
the narrative. They frame what they tell you. But you download your
data, you get the raw data,

but it's hard to
build, understand. We're HCI researchers. If you have a 70-megabyte JSON
file, there's no narrative here,

other than confusion
and frustration. And so we've been
really interested in, how do we provide our own
narrative for privacy?

What if we can control
this narrative? And how do we control
this narrative? How do we frame
this in ways that

might be compelling to people? And so we've said, well,
computer science is not

the end-all-be-all of the world. Data science is not the
end-all-be-all of the world, there are people who know a

about experiences. And so we've started

art in privacy,

and the role of provocations,

different artworks.

I've seen. I have too many hobbies. Whenever I go to

There was actually a

And this is just

And some of my

But we've also said, like,
as part of education, how do we think about

So, for instance,
we've had students. This is actually, on the

Em and Kevin, and then in

are really focused on making

what you're saying,

but they subversively change

We've had students do

mechanism for a plant

where it would automatically
water the plant? But it would only
water the plant and give it light if the things

were really positive

We've had students build

revealing information

about itself, and then uses

visits the exhibition. And so this is power of
large language models

and the power of the internet. We have had students look
at physical mechanisms,

like fog as a way
to protect privacy, but also to give a
false sense of privacy. So these students, for
one of their projects,

had filled a greenhouse with fog

and actually projected

on the outside what
was being tracked-- the person who thought they
were protected by the fog.

Which also led to

And I've gotten

Seeing, essentially, how

guessing attacks,

common passwords.

Meaning, if you say the
